awd_titl_txt: Chiroptical Sensing and Sorting by Structured Materials and Structured Light
awd_abstract_narration:
Chiral molecules are asymmetric molecules with left- and right-handed mirror images (called enantiomers) that cannot be superimposed.  The principal investigator will use rationally engineered metallic and dielectric nanostructures and structured light beams to substantially enhance sensing and sorting of chiral molecules via an entirely optical approach. This could lead to vastly improved particle and single molecule level detection over current methods. The development of a new class of novel chiral sensors can significantly improve the limit of detection and sorting of biomarkers of diseases and/or single molecules.

The proposed development includes, 1) use of chirality of optical fields to synergistically sense and manipulate chiral molecules, 2) fabrication of planar nanostructures using precision lithography techniques to create unique effects, 3) Potential use of nanocubes yielding highly unique sensing capability for sorting of chiral molecules as well as preferentially trapping molecules by chirality and 4) use of nanostructures for the development of ultrasensitive chiroptical spectroscopy using state of the art micro-/nano-manipulation techniques can lead to the development of new class of sensors for molecular sorting. 
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Chirality refers to the geometric property of a structure that is not superimposable on its mirror image. It is critical in biology, chemistry, and life science because many molecules, amino acids, and proteins are chiral. Consequently, identifying and separating chiral objects across different scales with high sensitivity, high speed, and low cost is essential. This project focused on chirality-dependent optical sensing and sorting using engineered nanostructures and light beams. Fundamentally, the research has offered deeper insights into the interaction between light and chiral matter. On the application side, the developed planar photonic structures hold promise for device integration in high-throughput sensing platforms. Additionally, the new techniques for ultrasensitive spectroscopy and all-optical manipulation are beneficial for many disciplines. To date, the project has led to 16 publications in scientific journals, including Physical Review Letters, ACS Nano, Nano Letters, Advanced Materials, Advanced Optical Materials, and Science Advances, as well as 20 keynote/invited presentations. Some key research highlights of the project are summarized as follows. (1) We experimentally demonstrated that dielectric metasurfaces can significantly enhance local superchiral fields and amplify the circular dichroism (CD) signals of chiral molecules. (2) We conceptually proposed and numerically demonstrated the use of metasurfaces supporting quasi-bound states in the continuum to generate strong enantioselective optical forces, which could be applied to sort and separate chiral objects. (3) We developed an innovative approach for chiral sensing by utilizing hydroxypropyl cellulose (HPC) as a chiral medium to form a hybrid system with phenylalanine. Through CD measurements and direct color observation of the HPC/ phenylalanine mixtures, we successfully determined the chirality of phenylalanine molecules, enabling efficient and high-sensitivity chirality detection.

Broader impacts: The innovative photonic platforms, as well as the spectroscopy and sorting techniques developed in this project, promise to efficiently identify, discriminate, separate, and manipulate various chiral objects at the nano-, micro-, and macro-scales. These advancements will help researchers investigate many viruses and diseases, and discover new medicines and drugs to benefit the public, as chiral structures play important roles in these areas. This highly interdisciplinary project also offered valuable training opportunities for students. It supported three Ph.D. students who made direct contributions to the project. Through their involvement, the students acquired fundamental knowledge and developed a broad range of skills in nanophotonics, chiral optics, materials science, physical chemistry, biosensing, and nanofabrication, which facilitated their career development. One Ph.D. student received the Dissertation Completion Fellowship at Northeastern University, and joined Polytechnique Montréal as a postdoctoral fellow after graduation. PI Liu has integrated some of the project’s findings into his courses, including EECE 5647 "Nanophotonics" and EECE 7284 “Optical Properties of Matter,” to educate students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.
